6981 I totally love this place.
6982 It reminds me of the old school hardcore Chinese restaurant my parents used to take us when we were kids :D
6983 The decor is amazing- unlike more Chinese places in Phoenix.
6984 The walls are a teal blue, adorned with large carved pieces of artwork depicting scenes in China, golden dragons and more.
6985 The lights hanging from the ceiling are amazingly ornate.
6986 The place looks like its from a bygone era (doesn't help that its in a run down strip mall) but it is clean and charming inside.
6987 The service was great- kind to our 2 yo, and very attentive.
6988 The food was the best part- I can't remember the last time I had such good Chinese food, and it's priced very reasonably.
6989 We got the Peking dinner for 2 which included the fried noodles, hot tea, wonton soup (with generous noodles, meat, shrimp and veggies, the best I've ever had), a pupu platter with eggrolls, bbq skewers, house wings and those cheese puff thingies (the presentation is pretty cool, too).
6990 Next came 3 entree sized plates of food: mongolian beef, fried chicken (can't remember the name) and the Peking fried rice.
6991 The meal concluded with incredible little desserts- sort of like eggrolls but filled with banana and then covered with crystalized honey.
6992 I could have eaten 100 of them!
6993 Adding in a beverage and tax, the meal was only $34!
6994 My 2 yo can really eat, so I am surprised and pleased to say that even with sharing the dinner for 2 people with him, the 3 of us walked out with lots of leftovers.

7031 You know how all big box chain restaurants throw junk up on the walls in an attempt to make the space feel vintage?
7032 Buca Di Beppo throws junk, and knick knacks and statues and anything else 'italian' they could find in the chinese warehouse where they loaded up these goods.
7033 It's a terrible horrible mess and you end up sitting in a yardsale of italian paraphenalia while eating your very bland pasta.
7034 It's embarassing how truly flavorless the food is here.
7035 Thin, flavorless alfredo sauce.
7036 Thick slabs of lasagna with less taste than what I can get out of the frozen section at Publix.

7039 Deep down you know they hate this.
7040 Why are we in the kitchen?
7041 Sure it's nice, but I'd rather have them concentrating on making the food, and making it good.
7042 Of course, the food at Buca Di Beppo seems to be far beyond any point of return to tasting good.
7043 It's just dead.
7044 Dead food.
7045 No life, no flavor, not emotion.
7046 I get more flavor from the $.99 Michelina's frozen lunch package.

7049 No salt, no sugar, no butter, no fat, it's all gone along with anything resembling taste.
7050 Sure, Buca has huge portions, and the setup is nice for large parties and families - but they might as well just buy the family-size pasta packs from the frozen section and bake it at home, even that would be better, and they wouldn't have to the mandatory gratuity.

7179 4 dollars"

7184 me: "It doesn't say that anywhere on the menu or walls"
7185 guy: "No, do not sell one slice.
7186 me: "what the...

7188 guy: "you buy two slices then."
7189 me: "yes, Jesus Christ, yes"

7191 me: "no, no toppings.
7192 cheese."
7193 guy: "we have toppings."

7195 me: "no thanks"

7401 Enjoy
7402 Y'know, rarely do I buy the "extended warranty" that most places try to peddle on you nowadays.
7403 If you buy the item from a reputable manufacturer, it should be unnecessary.
7404 In the case of tires, I have to make an exception.
7405 You can control the quality of tires you buy and put on your car, but not the quality of construction workers who don't know how to secure their nails, screws and bolts for travel on highways, streets and other local thoroughfares.
7406 They're a nefarious bunch for the most part.
7407 I'm not for extra taxes, but I'm contacting my local elected officials to institute a tax on all businesses who transport these little metal devils on the streets we drive...and stiff penalties/massive fines if they get caught dropping a load of these on the highway.
7408 For the second time in a year, one of my tires caught one of the little buggers -- this last one was not a nail or screw, mind you, but a BOLT.
7409 I pulled my receipts from the glove compartment, used Yelp to find the nearest Discount Tire, and called for a tow.
7410 The replacement certificates I got were $16 per tire (back in NC, but they're good here too), and worth every penny.
7411 The folks at this Discount Tire location were extremely nice, and had me in and out of there in about 30 minutes (with no appointment).
7412 There is even free water for customers.
7413 They were able to fix the tire instead of replacing it, which is fine (as long as it holds).
7414 Every Discount Tire location I've visited has been great as far as the transparency of what you're getting, the quality of customer service, and the wait.
7415 In a town of 4.3 million people and never-ending road construction, I have to recommend the free replacement warranty on your tires, no matter where you buy them.

7456 This happened to me as I transitioned from the salad to main dish, but when I took the mushrooms home in a to go box and ate them later, the more delicate flavor showed through and I appreciated it a lot more.

7590 I was inspired to visit Casella's after a coworker told me about their authentically Italian goodness.
7591 As my tummy growled today, I was in the neighborhood so I knew just where to go.
7592 I walked into a simple yet clean deli.
7593 Immediately, I was welcomed by the entire staff (I believe they are all related or at least family through friendship).
7594 They asked me if it was my first time in and I said yes, so right away they started giving me a history of the shop and the tasty cuisine.
7595 Celebrating their 33rd anniversary (congrats!!
7596 ), I learned that everything is homemade -- from the meatballs to the chicken salad.
7597 The owner said he goes through 40 lbs of chicken a week.
7598 He gave me a sample and the chicken was chunky and delicious.
7599 I'm not surprised he has to prepare so much chicken every week!
7600 The meatballs and freshly cut meat for Philly Cheese-steak sandwiches looked great too!
7601 The owner mentioned he is from Philly so better be ready for some authentic Philly and Italian style cookin'!
7602 While I was there, the owner was slicing some fresh provolone, so I added that to the warmed turkey sandwich I ordered.
7603 The turkey was tasty, the provolone was yummy and the sourdough roll tasted like it was fresh from the oven.
7604 It was $8 for a sandwich and soda but the sandwich was hefty enough that I saved half for later.
7605 As I walked out, everyone said goodbye to me and I felt like I was leaving a family dinner.
7606 In summary, here's what made Casella's stand out:
7607 - The very friendly staff
7608 - It's a local family-owned neighborhood deli celebrating their 33rd anniversary.
7609 Gotta support the local businesses!
7610 - Clean decor
7611 - Tasty, homemade food that's on display for visitors to see
7612 - A good family-style atmosphere that greets you the second you walk inside.
7613 I'm not sure how it's taken my so long to find this local treat, but now that I've found it, I plan on becoming a regular.

7730 Unlike other reviewers, I didn't like the buffet, though my friends from work think it's a good value.
7731 However, I've been going for dinner to Flavors of India for nearly three years now, and have ALWAYS liked the food.
7732 FOI is my first choice for Indian cuisine in Phoenix, out of the four other Indian restaurants in the valley I've tried.
7733 Yes, FOI is in a strip mall, but once inside, the ambiance is pleasant.
7734 It seems quite clean, I never got sick from anything I ate there (that's saying a lot, as I admit to being a fussy eater), and the waitstaff is helpful.
7735 Bollywood videos on the large flat-screen wall display in the corner are an unusual feature, but the volume is low or completely muted, so you can watch or choose not to, it isn't distracting.
7736 (Here's a footnote about that: I ate at FOI on the night of the presidential primary election.
7737 My dining companion noticed that most of the waitstaff was gathered around the TV in the bar, watching electoral results, so he asked our waiter if we could watch too.
7738 After getting the enthusiastic okay from the two other occupied tables, it was quite late in the evening, silent Bollywood was replaced by live news coverage with volume turned on).
7739 Regarding the food: I love their mattar paneer (cooked peas in a tasty curried gravy, with small cubes of homemade mild-tasting cheese).
7740 My super-spicy friend gets the lamb vindaloo (super-spiced as he requests).
7741 Tandoori shrimp, chicken and tikka masala are good though a bit pricier, the samosa appetizer (lightly battered and deep-fried cut vegetables) is fresh, warm and crunchy.
7742 Regular and garlic nan bread are everything they should be, biryani rice is overpriced (I'd stick with basmati rice as a side dish), and sweet lassi (a well-chilled dairy drink, similar in taste and consistency to a vanilla yogurt smoothy) is a nice treat.
7743 My spicy friend says his gin-and-tonic was weak, and they don't have ingredients to make a Bloody Mary, but hey, FOI is an Indian restaurant, so I can't fault them too much for that!
7744 Other pluses: open a bit later than many Phoenix restaurants (seating ends at 9:30 pm); very fast with takeout orders; there's lots of parking; the 16 North bus stop is nearby; silverware, glasses, white cotton tablecloths and napkins are always spotlessly clean.

7759 There are 3 choices at ASU for game design.
7760 Which one you choose depends on why you want to study game design.
7761 1.
7762 Polytechnic = Games are an engineering problem.
7763 If you are interested in the engineering of games - go there.
7764 The college of technology and innovation http://interactive.asu.edu/?q=hom
7765 2.
7766 Tempe = Games for (Education, Medical, Legal etc) They are closely tied with the education department and the Games for Impact initiative.
7767 http://cidse.engineering.asu.edu/
7768 3.
7769 West = Games as Art (Fine Art) If you want to explore games as a medium and art form this is where you want to go.
7770 You can either get a BA -http://newcollege.asu.edu/harcs/degrees/majors/interdisciplinary-arts-and-performance-program or a BS http://newcollege.asu.edu/mns/degrees/computing/applied-computing-program

7853 I violated my rule of avoiding grocery shopping while hungry and decided to venture over to Whole Foods.
7854 Whole Foods tends to be the indecisive individual's nightmare (that would be me).
7855 Yet, this store is a foodie's dream.
7856 There are aisles upon aisles of glorious, wholesome products (pun intended).
7857 Everything is meticulously organized and there are at least ten varieties of every type of item.
7858 No joke.
7859 It took me fifteen minutes to decide which brand of bottled tea would be suitable (and economical).
7860 I roamed the freshly prepared food section like a vulture circling it's prey...strategizing which choice would be the best taste sensation.
7861 Did I want a made-to-order wrap?
7862 Or a glass of wine and a couple tapas?
7863 (the live music was alluring)...Maybe sushi?
7864 Pizza?
7865 Salad bar?
7866 Soup?
7867 Maybe something from the smokehouse...oooh!
7868 A cupcake from the cupcake bar?
7869 On and on it went.
7870 My final decision was sushi.
7871 The spicy tuna roll tasted fresh, and the Pacific salad roll was very crisp.
7872 I also grabbed a container of ginger for $1.99--not the artificially preserved pink variety--all-natural pickled ginger.
7873 Bliss.
7874 I purchased some cucumber salad from the salad bar as a side/palate cleanser.
7875 All in all, a very satisfying meal.
7876 Prices are a tad higher than your average grocery store.
7877 Then again, it is Whole Foods.
7878 A word of advise:  come with a game plan (e.g.
7879 a shopping list).
7880 If you don't define what it is you want prior to entering this store, you'll end up spending two hours and twice as much money than you anticipated.

7897 Once we went to Grimaldi's in Hoboken, NJ and weren't all that impressed.
7898 Yet the first time we ate at this Grimaldi's, we were blown away!
7899 Upon entering, you are enveloped by the aroma of pizza baking in a coal-fired oven.
7900 This is swoon-inducing---and I mean that in a good way.
7901 The smell almost has you believing that you are in a pizza joint with a coal-fired oven in the Northeast.
7902 When ordering pizza baked in a coal-fired oven, I like to get a plain cheese pizza.
7903 IMO, this is the best way to fully taste the sauce, cheese and crust without anything else get in the way.
7904 There's nothing like a thin crust pizza from a coal-fired oven with that char on the crust.
7905 The crust has just the right balance of crispy and soft.
7906 The sauce is well flavored with proper proportions of basil and oregano.
7907 The amount of cheese is just right.
7908 I love to savor each and every bite.
7909 There is more to this Grimaldi's than the one under the Brooklyn Bridge.
7910 This one has other items in addition to the pizza.
7911 We like their antipasto.
7912 It has sliced mozzarella which is fresh and creamy, black and green olives (the black ones are pitted, the green ones have pits in them),  roasted red pepper slices which are bursting with flavor, and a good, flavorful salami.
7913 Everytime we're in AZ, it is so worth it to us to deal with the heavy traffic in Old Town Scottsdale to dine at Grimaldi's!

7915 Phone was not dropped or mishandled, just cracked and "owner" would not honor their warranty.

7926 You can get salad, fries, onion rings or half-half (half fries half onion rings).

7929 Overall, good food, I can't wait to come back and try something else from their special menu.

7937 Now, I'm not a fan of pizzookie, but wow, their cookie platter was awesome.

8276 I might have to do a gluttonous double order or sip-taste from a friends selection.

8279 I've also had a panini there and it was quite tasty and filling--I took leftovers home.
8280 My only wish is that the space Tea Infusion is housed in was more spacious with lounge seating in addition to table options so one can really settle in and work or chat with friends, but heck, I'm just happy they're here and serving the valley some tea-tastiness.

8373 WORST TAXI SERVICE EVER.
8374 There are certain people in your life that you should have & trust.
8375 A good mechanic is high on that list.
8376 I found out about Whitey's Auto through twitter.
8377 Many of my friends were communicating with Scott, the GM, and I started following him too.
8378 His tweets were funny, authentic and relevant- and not always about auto repair.
8379 The most important aspect of his tweets?
8380 They're immediate.
8381 At the time, I had a warranty through the dealership on my car so I didn't need to go to Whitey's for service.
8382 However, when I got into a car accident and tweeted about it, Scott responded for me to call him and he'd help me out.
8383 Although Whitey's doesn't do body work, their neighbor 1st Class Auto Body does.
8384 Scott personally walked me over there and made sure they treated me right.
8385 He had made me a lifelong customer at that point.
8386 When my boyfriend's truck kept leaking oil and he wasn't getting results at the shop he was taking it to, I took him to Whitey's and introduced him to Scott.
8387 With one check, Scott could tell that the previous shop had NOT done what they had charged my boyfriend for.
8388 Scott told him if he didn't mind the leak, he could put off the service work as it wasn't something imperative.
8389 And he didn't charge him for the assessment.
8390 Recently the belts on my car fell off, causing my a/c to go out & lights to come on my dash.
8391 My warranty was over, but I didn't even hesitate.
8392 I just turned right around and took my car to Whitey's.
8393 Replacement belts and labor (plus they checked my battery and charged it for me) cost $80 less than it would have at the dealership.
8394 The inexpensive cost, along with piece of mind that comes with dealing with a mechanic and shop you can trust, make Whitey's irreplaceable.
8395 Don't hesitate to take your vehicle there first when you need service!
8396 I would never have picked a museum cafe for lunch, even though it is practically in my own backyard, but with my friend's endless ravings about their Dreamcatcher Salad, I relented.
8397 And I'm glad I did!
8398 It's now become a staple for lunch meetings!
8399 The dining area is bright and cheerful, but the outdoor patio is truly a delight on a beautiful day!
8400 It is serene and is surrounded by a plethora of desert plants and a lovely water feature.
8401 The menu is rather short on items, but long on freshness and flavor.
8402 Many of the offerings lean towards Southwestern style.
8403 I have found my favorites on the menu, in particular, the Hummus Veggie Wrap which is filled to the brim in a healthy spinach tortilla with Tepary bean hummus, tomatoes, roasted red bell pepper, grilled red onions, pepitas, smoked gouda, and romaine.
8404 (I've tried to duplicate this wrap at home with underwhelming success!)
8405 Each sandwich comes with the choice of salad or chips.
8406 The portions are hearty.
8407 The service is attentive, but not intrusive.
8408 An absolutely divine dine!
8409 Pizzeria Bianco: Before and After
8410 Cited as "the best pizza in America" in numerous on-line reviews as well as on Good Morning America and as published in, Slice of Heaven, to most pizza lovers the three to four hour wait for a table is so daunting that they push on to a more open table atmosphere for their pizza experience.
8411 But to the true pizza enthusiast, Pizzeria Bianco is as much about the experience as it is the food.
8412 This place is best known for the owner Chris Bianco, hand tossing each and every pizza pie served every Tuesday through Saturday, from 5-10 pm for nearly 15 years, of which I was one of those fortunate customers.
8413 However, early 2010 Chris was forced to retire due to illness and turn over the pizza paddle and oven duties to his protégé of 15 years, Horatio Hernandez.
8414 My decision to try Pizzeria Bianco for the first time came from a challenge I put upon myself: Find the best food in metropolitan Phoenix.
8415 After hearing about Pizzeria Bianco from a friend, I made gourmet pizza my first battle in 2009.
8416 I knew about the long lines forming an hour or more before the restaurant opened, and this beautiful fall day was no exception.
8417 I arrived 60 minutes before opening and my date went to Bar Bianco to start us off with a couple of pale ale microbrews while I held our place in line.
8418 Seeing that there were only about 20 people ahead of us, we assumed we would make the 5:00 seating with no trouble.
8419 However, just as we were holding a place for the rest of our party, so were the 20 or so people ahead of us, and when the door opened promptly at 5:00, there were now over 50 people ahead of us.
8420 Needless to say we were left waiting another hour since the restaurant seats only about 40 at a time.
8421 When we were seated at 6:00, the four of us started with the homemade mozzarella, local tomato and sweet basil starter with extra virgin olive oil drizzled all over as well as homemade crusty bread with a dish of EVOO with a touch of balsamic added.
8422 We ordered three pizzas, the Sonny Boy providing salami, marinara sauce and gaeta olives, the Wiseguy a sausage and mozzarella taste explosion and the Marinara with Prosciutto di Parma.
8423 All three pizzas were piping hot when they arrived, just crisp enough around the edges and loaded with the most amazing flavors your mouth has ever experienced.
8424 We left the restaurant without remembering the nearly 3 hour wait and were fully satisfied, eager for the next opportunity to drive to 623 Adams in Phoenix for another "slice of heaven".
8425 And so, after hearing of the departure of Chris from the kitchen, curiosity got the best of me.
8426 I had to challenge this place and find out if the changing of the guard made any difference in the wait time, the food quality or the overall experience I had truly fallen for.
8427 April 6, 2010 again I ventured down to 623 Adams in Phoenix to see if a Tuesday night or a new head chef had made any difference at all.
8428 My date and I arrived at approximately 4:00 pm, one hour before the doors would open.
8429 We found a line of about 25 people and looked at each other and said, almost in unison, "Well, the wait hasn't changed".
8430 Bob trotted off to Bar Bianco to find our pale ale, Four Peaks to help pass the time.
8431 We caught a glimpse of owner Chris Bianco and I told Bob how I would love to chat with him seeing as I was writing a comparison review, I also wanted to find out who was cooking tonight.
8432 Bob stalked Chris into Bar Bianco and asked him if he had any time, would he be willing to take a picture with me and answer a couple of questions.
8433 When Bob returned with another beer and Chris Bianco in tow, I was star struck and could barely speak.
8434 All I could muster up was, "Are you cooking tonight?"
8435 To which he replied, "No, I have Horatio at the oven.
8436 I can't cook anymore."
8437 I explained my evaluative writing topic and he assured me the experience would be the same.
8438 We took a picture and off he went, back to the bar.
8439 At 6:15pm, after 2.25 hours of complete social enjoyment we were called to our seats at the bar.
8440 We ordered the same items we had enjoyed last fall with the exception of the Marinara.
8441 The overall experience was better for me as I got to enjoy personal time with Chris.
8442 As for the meal, it was just as amazing as I remembered it from 6 months prior with Chris tossing the pie for every customer.
8443 The flavors were exactly as I remembered and the service from the staff was top notch, just like the first time.
8444 From the wait to the taste, it didn't appear that anything had changed!
8445 So what makes for the "best pizza in America" and how did Pizzeria Bianco get the tag line?
8446 Well, my opinion is flavorful ingredients, a phenomenal social experience, and an owner who lives by what he serves.
8447 To Chris Bianco and the Pizzeria Bianco staff, you haven't skipped a beat!
8448 OK ok ok.
8449 I'll have to agree with some of the below reviewers that this place isn't dead-on authentic Mexican food.
8450 That being said, I love it!
8451 The place is huge, sporting a bakery (said many times before) with unbelievably dirt cheap pastries (not said as many times before), a little carniceria (not as good as Carniceria Sonora) and a huge dining area.
8452 The dining area with all its painted mural glory is so goddamn cool that I find myself wanting to just hang out there for hours watching La Primera Division de Mexico on TV and enjoying a nice $2 Dos Equis.
8453 The food - that's probably the only tougher part.
8454 Keep in mind it's still pretty good, but there are better places in the area for getting your Mexican on food wise.
8455 The potato taco is worth getting because it's fairly unique, but it came out so soggy that I had to eat it with a fork.
8456 I grabbed a couple of the Yelp-Advertised taquitos as well - keep in mind these are not the Circle K, rolling taquitos.
8457 They are literally just smaller tacos, but they were damn good.
8458 I guess when it comes down to it, I'm an atmosphere buff.
8459 There were so many cool things to check out in this multi-plex, and the atmosphere was so warm that I'd love to head back again soon.

8470 I am a 40-year-old woman who couldn't be happier with the care I have received and how I feel after seeing Dr. E for the past year.
8471 I recommend Dr. E to all my friends and family and the ones who actually listen have been very happy with their care as well.
8472 In response to Lisa N., it is possible that you are one of the few people who is immune to Botox and similar products, which is to no fault of the doctor.
8473 I too was extremely unhappy with subsequent treatments given by another doctor only to find out that no amount of the toxin would ever be effective for me because my immune system works too well.
8474 Ironic, isn't it?
8475 You should always do your homework when looking for a new doctor, especially when you know exactly what type of treatment you are seeking.
8476 For example, if you are simply interested in the HCG diet program instead of overall health and you had been elsewhere for less money then likely that place is a better match for you.

8988 I want to preface this review by saying that I'm close friends with one of the sushi chef's in training, so we got a seat right at the sushi bar and really had a great opportunity to chat.
8989 That being said, I will review this strictly on the quality of food, since we received some deep discounts due to being VIP guests.
8990 (C'mon now, you know you all get discounts too when you personally know the staff/chefs, so quit your whinin'!)
8991 The quality of the fish was excellent... some of the best sushi I've had in my existence.
8992 The key to getting good sushi is to trust in the chef, and ask them what is fresh, and what they would suggest (omakase style).
8993 We had a sashimi appetizer platter to start which featured blue fin, yellow tail, o-toro (yes, the good stuff!
8994 ), and a few other pieces.
8995 Served with fresh wasabi root (not the hydrated green powdery stuff), this appetizer really woke our stomachs and senses.
8996 We had a few different rolls per the chef's suggestion, and all were spectacular (including some off the menu rolls).
8997 The kim bap roll was highly recommended, and the quality was definitely memorable, better than most Korean-mom kim bop rolls I've had in my life.
8998 We asked for ama-ebi (sweet shrimp), which was soft, tender, and sweet, with perfectly fried shrimp head to back.
8999 This was the first time I've had such perfectly made ama-ebi, and it's made me want to continue my search in Chicago.
9000 Some tasty mochi desserts, a few bottle of sake, and all in all, it was a very enjoyable night for my compadres and I.
9001 I'm sorry for those that have found a bad experience at Otaku, as it sounds like most of it is waitstaff issues... but as a sushi fanatic, my advice to you is this:
9002 1.
9003 Don't ask for a table if you're party is smaller than 4... ask for a spot at the sushi counter, because that's how sushi is meant to be served.
9004 Getting to know your chef, the chef getting to know you, having drinks together, etc.
9005 2.
9006 Ask the chef what he/she recommends.
9007 Not all fish are equally fresh, and the chef will know what's best for the day.
9008 And if you can provide them with your own past experience of what you liked/didn't like, they'll likely craft a sushi experience for you that you'll love.
9009 Verdict:  If only Otaku were in Chicago...
9010 I might go broke.
9011 Delicious sushi, and worth a visit!

9079 How precious.
9080 I was fortunate enough to be near one of the only DMVs open on Saturday (Seriously?
9081 Three DMVs open on Saturday for the entire Valley?)
9082 After receiving such a magnificent welcome, I knew this was quickly going to be among the most painful experiences of my life.
9083 To simplify what was so bad, let me make a list of what I feel constitutes acceptable behavior in public:
9084 1) Bathe.
9085 The combination of water and soap, along with massaging the skin, creates an outcome that is most pleasing.
9086 Be sure to scrub behind your ears and reference this website about another notorious spot : http://www.craigslist.org/about/best/htf/755891987.html
9087 2) Sit still.
9088 Yes, I know we're all waiting here for about an hour.
9089 But tapping your foot, rocking back and forth in your chair or bouncing your leg aren't going to make time go any faster.
9090 Trust me, I was watching the clock.
9091 If you feel anxious, get up and walk around.
9092 3) Leash your children.
9093 If they cannot sit quietly, leave them in the car.
9094 It's winter, they'll be fine.
9095 It's not cute when your little monster is running up and down the aisles with his honey bun squeezing out between his fingers.
9096 It's even more not cute when he fake-falls five times in a row right in front of me.
9097 4) Maintain quiet tones and ensure appropriate conversations when taking/making calls.
9098 To the lady behind me, I'm sorry you're not that experienced in stripping.
9099 The first thought that popped into my mind was you had a failed audition for Le Girl.
9100 Thanks to your continued conversation, I was able to figure out you were a woodworker.
9101 5) Acknowledge the humans around you.
9102 Yeah, I get it.
9103 I'm not that big.
9104 In fact, if I turn sideways I disappear.
9105 But, I'm still right in front of you so pay attention, quit bumping in to me and hitting my leg.
9106 Unless that was flirting, in which case you really need to find someone more your level.
9107 Oh, the DMV: You have a brilliant recipe for dashing dreams and gutting humanity.
9108 And you manage to do it in a painfully lit room that reeks of a combination of my brother's old gym shoes and my dad's dirty underwear.
9109 There has to be an award for that, but I don't have the motivation to research it.
9110 Oh, and F724 was my number upon entering.
9111 I spent and hour and 15 minutes looking at that slip of paper.

9545 Deserves credit as a Phoenix landmark Chinese restaurant.
9546 This restaurant has been here for 38 years.
9547 I've been going here off and on for 35 years.
9548 I go here more for sentimental reasons, and not so much for the food.
9549 The interior still retains some of the original decoration style from the original restaurant established nearly 40 years ago.
9550 The rest of the decorations have been torn out.
9551 I believe the decor is modeled after the Forbidden Palace in Beijing - see the vault-of-the-heavens style crenelations in the ceiling.
9552 I have this restaurant - in its former self - to thank for this:  Back in its day, this restaurant was really great, and the entire atmosphere lent to an ambiance that actually inspired me to study Chinese and then later go live over there for some years.
9553 Sadly, the food here is not all that good.
9554 The fryer oil they use here is pretty old.
9555 The fried rice arrives looking almost black (from the fryer oil?
9556 too much soy sauce?)
9557 instead of a rich golden brown, and tastes overcooked somehow.
9558 The eggrolls are just OK.  Definitely not fresh.
9559 A lot of the menu items from the original owners are no longer on the menu; for example the special "Chinese cakes" served on a plate topped with a delicious gravy-like brown sauce and shallots - probably some form of Cantonese food.
9560 All of this is gone, and replaced by very plain fare, and not very good at that.
9561 If you like salty, greasy, plain-tasting yet somehow edible Chinese food not far from the $1-per-scoop variety, then go here.
9562 Golden Phoenix's heyday as a great restaurant is long-gone.
9563 Let us bow our heads in sadness to a place that once was very good - now passed on...
9564 Love this place, it's on our dinner rotation.
9565 The owners and wait staff always greet us since we are regulars.
9566 Great place and cheap too.
9567 Try the #100 its the best ever.

9585 Owned and operated by Eugenia Theodosopoulos (an Ohio native, fyi) and considered by many to be the best patisserie/bakery in the state I approached Essence with a note of skepticism largely assuming much of the hype was derived from Tempe's plethoric college crowd but arriving at the doors of the small shop on a particularly lovely 80 degree morning I gathered quite quickly that my original conceptions were misplaced; not only does Essence not look like a college haunt, neither do its prices or products - a vast selection of at least twenty items aside from the posted menu sitting beneath and atop a glass case forcing me to make more than one tough decision that was not helped by my server's accurate assessment that everything was really good.
9586 Now bearing in mind that the original impetus to visit Tempe on this particular morning was to visit Caffe Boa and that Essence was more of 'pre-meal' activity what follows may seem slightly gluttonous, but to be fair once I took my first bite of Theodosopoulos's École Lenôtre trained almond croissant I knew I was in good hands and everything else just sort of followed.
9587 Without a doubt my favorite breakfast pastry and perhaps my favorite French pastry overall, Essence's $3 twice baked option arrives slightly smaller than the average but with a shell that crackles to the tooth and an interior that is at once yawning pockets of air and nearly overloaded with butter and light frangipane there is no doubt that this is a case of "big things in small packages," and particularly in its still-warm morning state the flavors and textures rivaled those at Dominique Ansel and Payard Las Vegas for best I've had stateside.
9588 Moving next from the baked goods to one prepared from the menu my second taste of the morning aside from the slightly earthy and lightly leather accented coffee was Essence's "Signature" French Toast, a $7.25 selection featuring three griddled slices of eggy brioche and a sidecar of what I can best describe as banana infused caramel.
9589 Rich but thinly sliced and therefore nicely saturated each piece of the French Toast was exactly as it should be - the exterior crisp and the interior custard-while the sauce provided a pleasant balance of fruity notes and intrinsic sweetness that complimented rather than overwhelming the bread.
9590 At this point submitting to the fact that I was going to eat even the items I'd bought 'for later,' my next two tastes were a pair of $2.95 macarons that, much like the croissant, rivaled those both here and abroad in terms of taste and texture while opting for a much more rustic approach terms of size and presentation.
9591 Beginning first with Pumpkin Spice and then proceeding to Vanilla with Dark Rum each palm-sized cookie was exactly what one would expect from a well trained pastry chef as the exterior shell provided a slight crackle on bite subsequently giving way to a soft meringue followed by dense cream that slowly dissipated on the tongue - the cinnamon and nutmeg notes of the former particularly notable while the rum in the second was appropriately understated thus serving to highlight the vanilla of the shell.
9592 If there were any 'misstep' on the morning, it *might* have been the "Summer Berry Croissant Bread Pudding," though when I say misstep I must temper the comment with the fact that my quibble is only that I prefer the French/English take on the dish while this one was more based on the French Custard style, a rich vanilla bean pudding without a lot of crunch or textural variance but instead laden with blackberries, raspberries, and strawberries plus a sidecar of lightly sugared strawberries.
9593 Focusing more of the natural sweetness of the fruits and aromatics of the vanilla than the typical overly sweet versions served stateside it was more panna cotta than bread pudding to me, but chalking that up to personal tastes it was still delicious.
9594 Moving last to the one dish that gave me trepidation, the "French Napoleon" gave caused pause not only because the name clearly skewed towards a subset unfamiliar with a proper Mille-Feuille but also because so many pre-made versions of this layered pastry have failed to wow in the past...thankfully this was not the case at Essence.
9595 Featuring light and crunchy layers of choux easily withstanding the tines of a fork without turning into a smooshy mess (see "Mille Feuille New York") intertwined with rich pastry cream speckled with dots of vanilla bean and ripe raspberries what truly made this version stand out was the manner in which Theodosopoulos caramelized each layer of choux, a technique reminiscent of Pierre Herme and as good as the French icon's version was I'd be hard pressed to say Essence's was any less impressive.
9596 It would be awesome to see what they could do a la minut like Savoy, L'Arpege, or Genin and given the names I've dropped in the paragraphs above plus Essence's proximity I've no doubt I'll be returning to see what else the small shop is capable of soon.
9597 I'm on a community social action committee and have spent the last year planning a community-wide service day.
9598 We were each responsible to lead a team of volunteers in a different community service project and per my passion I chose the Humane Society.
9599 We arrived on Sunday afternoon with a group of 12 people at the Campus for Compassion on Dobbins Rd.
9600 Kathy - the head of volunteer services - met with us and gave us a thorough introduction.
9601 She included the history of the AZ humane society and the process and procedures by which they take-in and shelter animals.
9602 She really focused on promoting spaying and neutering pets and cited some very impressive statistics.
9603 Did you know that over 7 years un-neutered  cats can breed to reach 420,000 in numbers??!!!!
9604 and dogs 67,000??!!!
9605 thats CRAZY and so compelling.
9606 Kathy proceeded by giving us a very educational tour of the facilities... we saw dogs, horses, cats and bunnies.
9607 It was very eye-opening.
9608 First off it shattered any stigma you have about a shelter.
9609 The animal accommodations are so impressive!!
9610 The dogs have BIG size kennels with indoor and outdoor spaces that are really spacious.
9611 I was nervous to go in and see the dogs in kennels but I really wasn't as heartbroken as I thought I'd be bc they really had nice size spaces.
9612 There are sprawling lawns in the back where animals can run and play which even include a public dog park!
9613 There are also private puppy rooms.
9614 The cats have big crates as well and even private bedrooms where they can hang out in groups and the facilities were squeaky clean w/o any odors.
9615 The volunteers were so nice, kind and devoted to the animals.
9616 We got to feed horses, play with cats and bunnies and put together leashes for dogs.
9617 The most encouraging thing though was that the place was busy on a sunday!
9618 buzzing with people wanting to adopt pets and several cats were actually adopted during the 2 hours we were there.
9619 It was a wonderful and meaningful experience and I encourage anyone who is looking for a pet to adopt from the Humane Society and to look into volunteering with them

9848 It seems like a great idea.

9850 They also claim that the beef is local, hormone free, etcetera....

9852 tomato and lettuce, with mayo and mustard on a potato bun.

9860 2.
9861 They had places to sit but it's tiny and full.
9862 3.

9882 Then a greasy glop of what must have  been the mushrooms and onions slid out.
9883 Still not seeing any cheese, mayo, or mustard anywhere.
9884 Just oil.
9885 Tons and tons of oil.

9887 The other side of the bun has some mayo and mustard residue--and more oil.
9888 I'm grossed out, but hungry.
9889 I take a bite.
9890 It's not rare,  It's well done and oddly, tastes very faintly of liver.

9894 or beef, or SOMETHING, I just taste that faint livery taste.
9895 So I take another bite.There isn't even any salt or pepper, or anything on the burger patty.
9896 This is perhaps, the worst grade of meat available for human consumption.
9897 I take a third bite because that second bite brought back a memory of when I worked for a meat company here in town.

9948 Ok, so I have to share my morning experience.
9949 But first I must start off by saying this: I'm no moron.
9950 Honest.
9951 So, this morning I stopped for gas.
9952 My tank was getting dangerously low and there was no way I'd make it to work.
9953 That's okay, for I allotted time this morning for re-filling my tank.
9954 From my casa, I turned East on Indian School, vaguely remembering there's a Quick Trip nearby.
9955 Perfect.
9956 I had stopped there before.
9957 But it wasn't a Quick Trip I saw at the corner of Central and Indian School.
9958 Not wanting to risk running out of gas, I opted to stop here, at this ampm station.
9959 I pulled up to the closest gas tank, got out of my car, took off my gas cap and reached for the gas nozzle.
9960 Only then I discovered there was no pay-at-the-pump option.
9961 The short notice on the pump said to select my grade and start filling.
9962 "Wow," I thought, "It's so odd for a station to trust people - especially in this area - to not drive off without paying."
9963 So, I followed the instructions, but nothing happened.
9964 I kept hitting the grade button.
9965 It kept beeping back at me.
9966 Still nothing.
9967 To top it off (no pun intended), the nozzle was wrapped in this huge rubber tube thing that compressed when I applied pressure to the handle.
9968 I had never seen anything like it.
9969 Thinking my particular pump was fuct up, I pulled my car up to the next one.
9970 That's when I saw it - this strange machine, like an Amtrack ticket dispenser.
9971 I approached with curiously.
9972 That's when I realized.
9973 You swipe your card at this central machine (or deposit cash, if that's your preference) and then go back to your pump.
9974 Ah-ha.
9975 This is how this station works.
9976 So, I did just that.
9977 I punched in my gas pump number (4) and went back to my car to re-fill the tank.
9978 Already annoyed at this point, I figured I'd pump enough gas to get me through the next couple of days.
9979 Only, it wasn't pumping.
9980 The long rubber thingy was hindering my ability to hook the nozzle up to my gas tank.
9981 UGH.
9982 So, that's when I flexed my muscles and applied enough pressure to squeeze out $12 worth of gas.
9983 Then I re-hooked the nozzle on its perch and walked back to the strange machine for my receipt - it told me to do so when I swiped my card.
9984 Only, no receipt came out.
9985 I punched the keypad with defiance and walked off.
9986 Stupid ampm station.
9987 Since when does any gas station benefit from being different?
9988 I'm so used to pay-at-the-pump; you just swipe your card, select your grade, pump your gas, grab your receipt and go.
9989 Quick Trip doesn't torment me like this.
9990 There is no rubber nozzle thingy in my way.
9991 Grr.
9992 Screw this.
9993 I'm never going back there again.

10142 Over the years, Honey Moon Sweets has been my go-to bakery for a special occasion.
10143 I've purchased the "basic" cake for birthday parties.
10144 Let me just note here that a basic cake from Honey Moon Sweets is practically a masterpiece in any other bakery's mind.
10145 When planning my sister's baby shower, I knew exactly where to go.
10146 I wanted the perfect cake and a work of art to grace the baby shower table.
10147 And behold the Honey Moon Sweets baby cake.
10148 It was three tiers, blue with rattles, pacifier, building blocks, a crib, a teddy bear...you name it filling the top.
10149 Some of the pieces were frosting creations and some were real toys.
10150 It was almost too gorgeous to eat, but we couldn't resist it so enjoyed every bite.
10151 It was just as good as it looked if not better.
10152 Honey Moon Sweets does a fabulous job of using the freshest of ingredients and you can tell upon the first bite.
10153 The scariest part of this cake adventure was the travel time from the bakery to the Biltmore for the baby shower.
10154 One wrong move and the cake would have been toast so be prepared to move lightly with this cake in hand.
10155 As you can imagine, cakes from Honey Moon Sweets are not budget-friendly, but for what you get from the cake, it's reasonably priced.
10156 Just save your coins for a special occasion because it's worth it.

10202 I cannot recommend Phoenix Knife House enough.
10203 There are very few places where you can go and physically put your hands on so many different Japanese knives, which is obviously key in any knife purchase.
10204 If you've ever spent hours in the kitchen doing prep and chopping, blisters are a very real possibility if the knife doesn't fit.
10205 I've discovered over the last several years of cooking at home that I prefer a lighter and bolster-less knife for high speed chopping, which ultimately led me back to PKH for a purchase.
10206 Last year I purchased a Fujiwara 150mm petty for less than $60, and it's been a great knife; my girlfriend also likes it because it's light and maneuverable.
10207 She bought me a Misono UX10 for my birthday, which will ultimately replace my Henckels for most uses.
10208 Bottom line, go in, tap into Eytan's knowledge of the knives (and care and maintenance), and get better tools for the job.
10209 It's well worth it.
10210 I bring all my kitchen knives here to get sharpened, either by hand or on the grinding wheel.
10211 Today I had four knives sharpened, three on the wheel, one by hand, and two with tip damage.
10212 Total cost = $13.
10213 Bonus: purchases are tax free.
10214 Highly recommended.

10437 Pizza was my absolute favorite food in my past, gluten-filled life.
10438 Anything from Slices to Pizzaria Bianco.
10439 I have tried gluten free pizzas almost everywhere you can find them, and they are always too dry, too thin, too soggy, or completely different flavor than what pizza crust should taste like.
10440  Picazzo's gluten free pizza is delicious, the crust is pretty thick and has a good texture, not like a big saltine cracker as most places tend to be.
10441 the flavor is true to pizza crust!
10442 my friends even like it so much they will split a gluten free pizza with me instead of ordering 'regular' crust.
10443 There is also a range of appetizers that are delicious, caprese salad with gluten free bread and the spinach dip are my faves.
10444 The employees are all very nice and aware of gluten intolerance--they check with you before they bring you additional food items or before putting GF and non-GF foods together in your to go box.
10445 I love it.
10446 If you are gluten or wheat intolerant and  you like pizza, this will be your new favorite place.
10447 Totally worth the drive, and the money.
10448 But the prices are very reasonable for GF food!

10596 Troy, the owner, is a brilliant businessman!
10597 Being a pharmacist myself, I am familiar with the quality of his products and his facility.
10598 Trust me when I say his sterile compounding areas are more advanced than many hospitals in the Valley.
10599 After spending a day at his old facility when I was still training, I felt comfortable enough to send my mother to Troy so that he could help her with hormone replacement therapy.
10600 The docs around town trust him enough to let him dictate what a patient needs; they simply sign off on his recommendations.
10601 My mom has had a huge increase in her quality of life since seeing Troy, and I feel the compounded HRT is safer than the Prempro she used to take.
10602 Do not hesitate to consult a compounding pharmacist if you're having health issues that aren't being adequately addressed.
10603 Troy is one of the best in the Valley.
10604 It's worth the drive to consult with him, and further prescriptions can be mailed to your home.

10891 I stopped in with a friend on a Saturday night after a friend had recommended it to me and was totally thrilled we did.
10892 We sat at a table for sushi and waited no longer than 10 minutes for a table - amazing for 8 pm on a Saturday in old towne.
10893 Unfortunately, they had sold out of the oysters, but the other dishes we'd ordered were fabulous - starting with a seared tuna dish, then softshell crab roll, rainbow roll, and the green mussels.
10894 The seared tuna was cooked and cut perfectly - just the right temperature with a peppery "rub," the rolls were a decent size with thick cuts of fish and plenty of flavorful crab, and the mussels were a tad overcooked for my preference but the creamy texture and buttery flavor still made it a winner.
10895 The thing I appreciated most was actually the service - we weren't rushed or hassled, and the food came out a dish at a time, giving us a chance to eat and enjoy before getting our next dish.
10896 At other sushi joints, I am constantly feeling rushed while trying to fit all of the dishes on the table (and I'm not what you'd call a slow eater!).
10897 This was a happy medium for me.
10898 The server confirmed that we were ready for the bill instead of just dropping it off without asking - it's the little details that make a big difference to me.
10899 My only other con was creepy old men leering at us from the bar...but that's what you get in Scottsdale.

10909 Seek it out:
10910 Let me begin this review by saying that mine is not an indictment on this particular location but on every single P.F.
10911 Chang's I've had the misfortune of being dragged to.
10912 P.F.
10913 Chang's is effectively the Cheesecake Factory of bad Chinese food, with the disadvantage of not being as capable of delivering passable food.
10914 They bill themselves as a "gourmet" Asian experience, which is a bit of a laugh when they turn around and sell you their equally horrible frozen entrées right from the convenience of your local Wal-Mart.
10915 Everything is bland, overcooked, and ridiculously priced.
10916 Once you've paid nearly $14 for their "orange peel chicken", you may privately hope to yourself that they might have the audacity to include some fried rice.
10917 This is your second mistake.
10918 Sadly, the bistro calls you on your bullshit.
10919 You get white or brown--fried rice is several dollars extra and not at all worth it.
10920 Everything seems to be cooked just wrong--things that shouldn't be are too crispy, things that should be sauced are too dry, things that should taste good make you question the will of the gods, all the while you find there's no way to escape the treachery.
10921 Things get more and more frustrating as you dig deeper: P.F.
10922 Changs, while sounding vaguely Asian, is a wholly American creation.
10923 It was founded by Paul Fleming (in Scottsdale, actually) with SOMEone with some Asian influence to spice it up a bit, named Philip Chiang.
10924 (They literally cut out the poor bastard's "i" so that it would "fit on the signs better," or, as I like to believe, not scare away the flyover-states-white-folk so.)
10925 It's highly Americanized (and yes, I've had Chinese food in China, but I've also enjoyed great "American Chinese" food here) to the point of regrettable blandness and it is SO VERY EXPENSIVE you may find your credit score taking a ding after eating a plate of "wok charred beef", listed as one of the saltiest foods in America.
10926 The decoration is clumsy and their famous inclusion of terra cotta warriors are literally symbols of death.
10927 From Jennifer 8 Lee's Fortune Cookie Chronicles:
10928 'But not everyone finds the terra-cotta warriors charming.
10929 "Chinese people would never put that in a restuarant," Jim told me, pointing at the statues.
10930 "It's not lucky.
10931 It's something you put at a burial site!
10932 But in America, they think it's a Chinese thing."
10933 From a Chinese perspective, P.F.
10934 Changs is decorated with death.'
10935 Which is just fine, because everything there tastes like death anyway.
10936 As a frequent traveler into Scottsdale, I was looking for something new and different to celebrate with a young up and coming professional baseball player---who happens to be my nephew.
10937 We were forewarned this place had no prices on their online menu and appeared to be owned by Mastro's which consistently has excellent food.
10938 Michael Dominick opened Dominick's Lincoln Avenue Prime Steakhouse last fall after baseball season in the small, but excellent Scottsdale Quarter.
10939 (I'll admit to frequenting this Nike store in travels to Phoenix.)
10940 The ambiance is that of an elegant steakhouse.
10941 The rooms are dark with huge crystal chandeliers.
10942 Very opulent without being ostentatious!.
10943 We both ordered the bone-in filet which is an excellent aged prime cut.
10944 Supposedly, according to our very professional server, this cut is about 16 oz with a bone yielding about a 14 oz serving.
10945 My limit on steak is typical 6-8 ounces and I ate my entire meal, making me think (1) This place really is THAT GOOD, and (2) I doubt this is more than a 10 oz serving.
10946 We started with a warm assortment of breads and in deference to my guest, we minimized the veggie's ordered.
10947 (I'll go back during baseball season :-) )
10948 After ordering a glass of of the extensive, but reasonably priced wine list, we looked at dinner entree.
10949 The steaks come with a choice of rubs and sauces.
10950 The house rub was described as "cajun-style, but not overwhelming".
10951 My theory is sauces on steaks are useful for poor cuts of meat, but take away from great cuts; hence, I went no sauce.
10952 The result was an incredibly great dinner of Bone-in filets ordered medium rare, no sauce and a loaded mashed potato side.
10953 (This side comes pre-prepared or you can ask for ramikans of cheese, chives, bacon and sour cream and build as you like at the table.
10954 We finished with a scoop of ice cream and a cappuccino for desert.
10955 Excellent steak spot and a welcome high-end addition to the Scottsdale food scene.
10956 One comment: The "Branding" of the restaurant is confusing.
10957 Either call it "Dominick's" or "Lincoln Avenue", but not both.
10958 This actually caused confusion in trying to locate this spot and diminishes the feng shui and brand loyalty you'd want to keep and associate.
10959 (Qualifier: I'm not a branding expert and this is strictly my opinion.)
10960  I would love to see Mastro's try a southwest cuisine spot!

11042 If there was a Cantina Laredo in my home (Los Angeles) I would dine here regularly despite the multitude and variety of Mexican dining options.
11043 Needless to say, when I'm in Scottsdale, I often find myself drawn to Cantina Laredo.
11044 From the moment you're in, to the moment you're out, Cantina Laredo takes excellent care of your tastebuds.
11045 The chips are salsa aren't filler but a real treat.
11046 Their homemade salsas are worthy of bringing in your own jars to export back home -- some of my favorite salsa anywhere.
11047 I believe they have three different kinds.
11048 Their tequila options are wonderful allowing for creative margaritas or a fine neat glass of 100% pure agave goodness.
11049 (I promise to never use that phrase again, sorry Readers.)
11050 The entrees aren't just your common taco/burrito fare.
11051 Using juicy meats, creative homemade sauces, and interesting pairings, Cantina Laredo professes its love for Mexican food and culture -- reminding diners how lovable these things are.
11052 The decor and various areas are all quite nice as well.
11053 An excellent complement to what always proves to be an excellent meal.

11578 The Phoenix Art Museum was a day well spent.
11579 The atmosphere was inviting and it was like around every corner was a surprise waiting to be discovered.
11580 Admission was free for me.
11581 How you may ask?
11582 Our local library has cultural passes for various museums, try checking out your library next time you go.
11583 The museum was inexpensive adventure that took me across the world.
11584  All the different exhibits kept me intrigued and interested.
11585 There were paintings, drawings, photography, and sculptures galore.
11586 There were even some animated pieces.
11587 I even stumbled upon a piece you could actually walk through.
11588 The layout of the museum is very easy to follow, as they give you a map and everything is labeled.
11589 You can go from the Asian culture, to English within a matter of feet.
11590 It is mind blowing.
11591 The whole world seems so much smaller, and it's brought together so beautifully.
11592  They offer guided tours, or you can walk around by yourself.
11593 There is also a children's section to the museum.
11594 I have nothing bad to say about the museum itself.
11595 I am extremely happy that I went, and would recommend that anyone go.
11596 It would be a great date, or family day, or even a day by yourself.
11597 The Phoenix Art Museum is a place that I think everyone should visit while in Phoenix.
11598 It will really open up your eyes and make you think.

11787 I know it sounds weird but this ice cream is phenomenal.
11788 It was sweet, tangy and somewhat salty, all at the same time.
11789 Instead of just enjoying this ice cream alone I decided to make my own blue cheese sundae.
11790 They have many toppings to choose from, including bacon brittle.
11791 When all was said and done my creation contained two scoops of their Honey Blue Cheese ice cream topped with a salted caramel sauce, bacon brittle and a homemade marshmallow that was toasted with a blow torch.
11792 This sundae was exploding with flavor.
11793 Every bite was crunchy, salty, sweet, tangy and delicious.
11794 My fiancé had a waffle cone sundae that contained Salted Butter Caramel ice cream, Almond Buttercrunch ice cream, salted caramel sauce, brownie bites and a homemade marshmallow.
11795 Hers was also amazing.

11923 I've been a fan of La Bocca for a long time because it served the needs of an underserved demographic on Mill Avenue.
11924 Canteen offers many things that La Bocca does...and more.
11925 What is that demographic exactly?
11926 ...Late twenties, looking for something chic and classy without paying a ridiculous premium for those qualities.
11927 Mill has plenty to offer for the ASU kids and the older adults, but for those of us who lie somewhere in between, places like La Bocca and Canteen are just right.
11928 Canteen one ups La Bocca, in fact, because there are menu items included in happy hour (50% off most drinks and select food items).
11929 Here are the highlights:
11930 The margarita.
11931 It's a real margarita!
11932 (It's not a lime daiquiri masquerading as margarita.
11933 Loads of sour mix does not a margarita make.)
11934 The chips and salsa.
11935 Both fresh and delicious.
11936 The pico de gallo is particularly fresh and delicious.
11937  The ribs.
11938 Sweet and spicy...the level of heat from the habenero is perfect and the meat literally falls right off the bones.
11939 The ambiance.
11940 It's chic but not pretentious.
11941 My friends and I really enjoyed the Latin music.
11942 Our suggestion would be to emphasize that music and minimize the clubby stuff (it verges on Scottsdale).
11943 To contextualize some of the other yelper's comments.
11944 I was glad to hear that one yelper didn't find Canteen suited to his beer and Jaeger shot needs.
11945 There's a bar (or ten) down the street for that.
11946 For the yelpers that found the portions to be too small, I suspect they didn't understand the Mexican take on tapas that the taco menu is going for (in fact, the whole valley suffers from a lack of tapas locations).
11947 Finally, the service complains...my service has been cordial and attentive, even when super-busy.
11948 Folks, this place is new, let's let it go through it's growing pains before issuing such harsh judgments that might jeopardize the success of a really wonderful place.
11949 Beer is awesome (first timers must do the beer flight sampler) and I have never had a meal that wasn't excellent!
11950 A quick note, there isn't a/c in the building so keep that in mind during the summer months - although that doesn't stop anyone from going, the place is always jumping!
11951 Loooove this place!
11952 Yes it's pricey, but good sushi usually is.
11953 The guys making the rolls were friendly.
11954 The atmosphere is nice.
11955 Hubby absolutely loved the quail eggs and I couldn't get enough of the spicy shrimp roll.
11956 Seriously, try it.
11957 You won't be disappointed!

11962 Since there isn't a rake or fee, don't be cheap (like one guy there) and tip the dealer generously.

12091 What a sexy course this is.
12092 This ranks up there with some of the best courses I've ever played, and THE BEST desert course I have ever played!
12093 Yes it's desert links style golf, but you're in the desert so what do you expect?
12094 It's kind of a trek, but it'll be worth it.
12095 From the moment you arrive to the moment you leave you'll enjoy the service and scenery.
12096 A real private club feel.
12097 As mentioned earlier this is DESERT LINKS GOLF!
12098 No adjoining fairways, and all the crap plays as PGA desert (lateral).
12099 The fairways are pretty wide for the most part, so you can spray the ball a bit, but there is definitely some carry involved on some of the tee boxes.
12100 Hole 18 is a very hard core par 4.
12101 Long carry on the approach to the green with a TON of water along the right side of the fairway and green.
12102 This is the kind of hole that can ruin a good day on the course real quick.
12103 Don't be afraid to lay up.
12104 :)    Oh, and there are mens ratings for ALL the tee boxes, I'd recommend higher handicappers play from the forward tees, because this course could be really hard if you're a mediocre golfer...
12105 Maintenance was perfect, even in September after baking in the Arizona heat all summer.
12106 The fairways were well manicured, and not too hard.
12107 Nice rough, but not too tall.
12108 A slightly errant shot will be caught, but you won't have to worry about searching for your ball for 5 minutes either.
12109 The greens were also perfect.
12110 Nice and fast, and TRUE!
12111 Ok, I'm done gushing about this course...   Give it a shot, you won't regret it.

12134 I heart Sky Harbor Airport Parking...
12135 Of course, it's always nice to find a ride to or from the airport but when you're all out of favors and you have only yourself to rely on, it comes down to driving yourself or getting a taxi.
12136 Sky Harbor Parking to the rescue.
12137 For $8 a day or cheaper if you print the coupons from their website, the folks at Sky Harbor Parking make it easy to drop your car and get to your gate in no time... and I've used them a handful of times solo and with the BF so I know it's door-to-door consistent service.
12138 If you are interested in covered parking, call ahead, but otherwise, just drive over to Washington and 40th and they will take care of you from there.
12139 Also, I recommend calling from the airport once you have your bags and they are always good about picking you up within minutes to take you back to your car.
12140 I hope you'll find Sky Harbor Airport Parking as useful and convenient as I do... safe travels!

12189 We never really talked with the waitresses or knew their names, but they always knew what I wanted; I didn't have to order.
12190 They always gave me water with no ice no lemon, my husband's with ice and lemon, gave me my panang curry with chicken medium and waited for my husband to choose what he wanted.
12191 He probably ordered most of the items on the menu.
12192 They refilled my rice if I ran out without asking.
12193 Our bill always came to $19.53 for dinner more times than I can remember.
12194 We went maybe twice for lunch, but almost always for dinner.
12195 My husband graduated last month and we moved from Tempe but we miss this place dearly.
12196 Groupon rip-off.
12197 Small salad, three extremely small plates of mediocre pasta desserts that cloyed the palate.
12198 All for an advertised value of $90.
12199 Will NEVER return.

12201 His staff was very friendly and the facility is extremely clean.
12202 I have an 8 year old Boxer that needed a large tumor type growth removed from his paw and was given very high estimates from different hospitals.
12203 Phoenix Mountain Animal gave me a very reasonable price on the initial exam and the actual removal, stitches, etc... ended up being much more affordable than any place I had called.
12204 I was originally offered care credit( a payment plan) but I ended up not needing it because the bill was within reason.
12205 I just picked up my dog and he was a little sleepy from the local anesthetic, so we will see how the next few days go.

12263 Mekong Supermarket.
12264 I consider myself to be a huge fan of Asian cuisine.
12265 Chinese, Japanese, Filipino, Korean, Indian.
12266 You name it, I'll eat it.
12267 I have my healthy moments, but I am a seasoned eater and I am not afraid of exploring the world through my palate.
12268 Mekong is the perfect place for me to massage my senses.
12269 The aroma and sensations from the exotic product.
12270 The stunning visual of a catfish being bopped on the head, and then cut up and packaged.
12271 The cheesy elevator music on the loudspeaker.
12272 The delicious taste of a spring roll from the hot food bar.
12273 This place has it all.
12274 I usually come here for my Asian condiments and live seafood.
12275 Want a live crab?
12276 Boom.
12277 Done.
12278 Want spicy mustard or sriracha in a large bottle for cheap?
12279 It's yours.
12280 To me, there is nothing like taking the 10 mile drive in traffic to Mekong because I know I am going to get everything I want.
12281 Make the trek.
12282 You won't regret it.
12283 Okay, I will start out by saying that I just picked this place out because it was near a bar we were going to afterward.
12284 Boy Howdy, am I glad I found this little gem!

12301 The balsamic was excellent as well.
12302 I must now do peppers with my Caprese!

12306 I'm super happy it was!
12307 This is close to if not the BEST chicken dish I've eaten.
12308 The chicken was moist which is usually questionable in Italian restaurants I've found.
12309 The quality of the Fontina cheese was impeccable.
12310 The pancetta was crisp and plentiful.
12311 Then I tasted the mushrooms!!!!
12312 OMG!!
12313 Freaking amazing!
12314 I may have to try the Chicken Marsala sometime just to have more mushrooms!

12319 My husband loved both his veal dish and said the meat sauce was one of the best he's had.

12524 This place was the answer to my German grocery shopping dreams!
12525 I thank the Yelp community for leading me to Old Heidelberg.
12526 I was picking up a number of items for an Oktoberfest party I was cooking for and hosting at my house, and was able to fulfill most of my exotic German needs at this one stop.
12527 I picked up pumpernickel rye bread, authentic concentrated Maggi Würze seasoning (not the soy sauce-tasting stuff you find in most American grocery stores) and Knorr zwiebel-kräuter salat krönung.
12528 They also had lots of Knorr sauce mixes that you just can't find over here (for instance,  sauerbraten gravy).
12529 I stuck around for a few minutes to talk to the two women who ran the place (Andrea and Chris).
12530 I volunteered that I had lived in Germany for years, including Berlin and Bavaria.
12531 They were totally friendly and even suggested some other places nearby that I could check out for German grub or rarer German beer selections.
12532 I promised I would be back... especially since I spotted that they had frozen leberknödel (liver dumplings).
12533 I made these once from scratch years ago but that was a lot of work.
12534 Knowing that they carry such delicacies has snagged me hook, line and sinker, as I am now destined to return and once again indulge my German food fantasies.

12598 Here is my take on Hotel Valley Ho: The Good, The Bad and The Ugly.
12599 Good:
12600 1) Gigantic, comfy bed.
12601 I slept like a queen.
12602 2) Private balcony with large chaise lounge and sitting area.
12603 3) Outstanding bathroom.
12604 The tub is separate from the shower which is and the toliet has a room all to itself.
12605 4) Cool decor both interior and exterior.
12606 Bad:
12607 1) Bed pillows were too squishy.
12608 2) Toliet paper/bath tissue was surprisingly rough.
12609 I would expect a hotel of this caliber to have a softer tissue.
12610 3) The mini bar and console are fully stocked with an assortment of spirits, but no coffee or tea.
12611 Not everyone that stays here drinks his/herself into a stupor.
12612 Ugly:
12613 1) Parking is $15 per day, but you have the option to self park which doesn't cost a thing so I guess that's not really "ugly".
12614 Overall, we had a lovely stay at Hotel Valley Ho and look forward to our next visit.
12615 Coffee-meh.
12616 Not great, not horrible.
12617 Scone-dry.
12618 Service-ridiculously slow.
12619 The night we were there (8/11), the owner came and asked a group of people (who were clearly having some sort of meeting) to stop talking because they were "disturbing the guitar player."
12620 Chased 8 paying customers (at least I assume they were paying customers; they all had drinks) out the door.
12621 Weird!!
12622 Don't think I'll be going back.
12623 I would've gone 2 stars if I were more forgiving.
12624 I could reason that it was the end of the day, that a big crowd of wayward children had just come through, or that a hurricane had blown out the back of the restaurant.
12625 But then, I tasted it.
12626 It looks as if Yogurtini is pretty well-loved around these parts, and I'm sorry to report otherwise.
12627 It's was like a bomb had gone off.
12628 The tables were filthy, the machine handles were all gunked up, there was assorted debris on the floor.
12629 The two teenagers working were too busy gossiping about who knows what to do their jobs.
12630 When we walked in there were a few customers sampling flavors among the ruins, with no employees in sight.
12631 We grabbed some sample cups from the register and dodged napkins and froyo puddles (and other customers) to try some different flavors.
12632 The levers are the type that if you pull just a bit too far you make a mess all over your hand, especially when trying to squirt a tiny bit in a sample cup.
12633 This mess is then added to the greater mess of everyone else attempting this same operation, and no-one attempting to clean it up.
12634 The stuff was real overpowering, to where instead of tasting like what it was supposed to taste like, it was bordering on medicine or like a bad imitation of what it was supposed to be.
12635 Like, cheesecake doesn't taste like that, good cheesecake anyway... And neither does cake batter, or banana.
12636 Where did the yogurt part go?
12637 And how do you screw up cookies and cream, exactly?
12638 The two that were the best (and most edible) were the Irish mint and the red velvet, and that's what we mostly ended up with.
12639 The decor didn't add to our experience.
12640 Everything is a mint green, but it doesn't come off as retro or even minty, but more like dated and hospital-like.
12641 Some people really like it but I found it unappetizing.
12642 A surly teenager magically appeared as we approached the register, only to disappear again soon after we paid.
12643 We sat down at a dirty table and dealt with our choices while the two teens again made an appearance, half-mopping-half-attempting-to-clean while chattering back and forth about their dating woes.
12644 We finished our yogurt but both strongly considered abandoning the whole affair.
12645 I very well could have walked into Yogurtini at the worst possible time on the worst possible day, with all the factors stacked against them, but I won't be returning to find out if this was the case.

12732 They finally just opened a Rita's location in Surprise!!
12733 I think it just opened yesterday or today, but it's just as good as the one on Union Hills and 83rd Avenue.
12734 I told my co-workers about it and we basically have been driving by during our lunch break just waiting for it to open over the past few months.
12735 It's hard to explain the texture of the ice.
12736 It's thicker than the ice in a frozen margarita, yet it's not crunchy or unrefined like an Icee drink.
12737 Sonic has similar ice, but I feel like it's just not as good as Rita's.
12738 I guess that's why it's Italian ice.
12739 It's in its own category!
12740 There are 3 main types: Gelati's (custard-ice-custard), Blendini's (custard-ice-custard with mix ins like Oreos, M&Ms, etc), and Mistos (ice-custard drink).
12741 You can also get just regular custard alone or flavored ice alone.
12742 One of their most famous ice flavors is Swedish Fish.
12743 There's also a sugar substitute version of their ice and today's sugar free ice flavor was Pineapple.
12744 I tried a Red Velvet Cake Gelati today with vanilla custard and it was nothing less than amazing!
12745 The menu is a little confusing since there are so many choices.
12746 There are mainly only 2 types of custards though, vanilla and chocolate, that can be mixed with the 12 flavors of ice that consistently change.
12747 Before, I was solely a fan of ice cream and yogurt.
12748 Now, I am grateful that my sister-in-law dragged me here, because there is nothing quite like it yet!
12749 Now I will always compare Italian ices to this place.

12754 She was right.

13002 When I say "popped", I mean it was an electric shock wave pop flowing through my face to my freaking eyeball that made me tear up a little.
13003 (this was done by the needle of course going into my cheek)  It was the craziest feeling, but relieving at the same time.
13004 I just breathed through it, and it helped.
13005 After about a min, the Dr was working his magic.
13006 In about 45 mins, he was all done, and I had like 4 canals.
13007 And I didn't feel a thing!!
13008 :)
13009 I was very pleased with the staff, Dr Amin, and the work they did.
13010 I highly recommend this place if you need a root canal done.

13024 What is a pasty?
13025 A pasty's history can be associated with the tin miners in England.
13026 The story goes that these miners were covered head to toe in dust and other nasty stuff and would eat these calzone like dishes as a means to have nourishment without the need to return to the surface.
13027 Supposedly, the miners were able to eat the pastry like food by holding onto the "handles" and when done, discard the tainted remains into the mine thereby appeasing the spirits that haunted the mines.
13028 At the Cornish Pasty Co.
13029 I can first hand recommend the Chicken Pesto.
13030 Very good flavoring and filling.
13031 Or you can go with the more traditional route with beef, potatoes, and swede.
13032 The sauces that come with your pasty are there to accent the flavors and are highly recommend to try as well.
13033 Pros
13034 * Good food
13035 * Originality
13036 * Portions
13037 * Customer service
13038 * Coat hooks at the bar
13039 Cons
13040 * Small interior

13054 Located south of Chandler Boulevard, just off of Roosevelt (next to Archery HeadQuarters).
13055 Wanda's is a small yet quaint, twelve tables inside and 5 outside.
13056 Outside is for sure seasonal, as summers are too hot and dead of winter can be too cold.
13057 Wait times on a Sunday or Saturday can be 10-15 minutes during the "rush times", which is a quarter the wait time you would experiece at the near-by chains.
13058 The menu offers a variety to satisfy and hunger (except if you want lunch on weekends, it's breakfast all day, lunch from 11-2 during the week).
13059 The burritos are awesome.
13060 Ladies, I guarantee you will take half home!
13061 My husband likes the Biscuits and Gravy.

13066 I have been coming here since discovering them after their opening week last year and I haven't stopped coming back.
13067 The food is predominantly Filipino; the Filipino-Mexican fusion comes in the burritos, flautas and quesadillas filled with Filipino meat dishes.
13068 A great starter would be the Chicken Adobo burrito.
13069 Karey's does it right by not dumping rice and fillings inside the burrito; they're served on the side.
13070 For those more interested in rice plates and combinations, Karey's serves daily prepared dishes such as Pork Adobo and Chicken Adobo (pork or chicken simmered in garlic and soy vinaigrette) and Beef Mechado (a type of stew with beef chunks, potatoes, and onions in a light tomato gravy) with either white rice or Garlic Fried Rice (yummy).
13071 There are also specials that rotate each day, which can be checked out on their Twitter account.
13072 This is a great idea as one can find out when they are serving Lechon (roasted pig)!
13073 Yum!
13074 There are dishes that can be prepared fresh but are not part of the combination specials.
13075 The ones I've tried that I highly recommend are their Lumpia (fried eggrolls in chicken, beef, or vegetable) and Pancit Canton (stir-fried noodles with vegetables).
13076 The pork lumpia was great when they used to serve it, and I preferred it to the beef lumpia that they serve now...but it's still good ;)
13077 Not only is the food delicious but the warmth of the staff is something to always look forward to.
13078 Karen and Rey make you feel truly at home.
13079 The best thing about Karey's Kitchen is having a Filipino restaurant in Phoenix and not having to drive all the way to the East or West Valley!

13124 I have found my new favorite sushi spot.
13125 I wish it was closer to Tempe, but it's worth the drive.
13126 You can tell by their menu that Hana strives to be an authentic Japanese restaurant, as opposed to the sake bomber joint that only has food so they can call themselves a restaurant.
13127 You know the kind; the Phoenix area is plagued with them.
13128 Hana is BYOB, and there are only a few ridiculous fusion rolls on their sushi menu: most of it is authentic, real sushi.
13129 On my first visit I started with my usual appetizers, and was immediately struck by how unusually fresh and tasty they were.
13130 The seaweed salad had just the right amount of sesame oil, giving it incredible flavor.
13131 The veggie gyoza were indescribably delicious.
13132 They made me realize I'd never had a fresh gyoza before; every one I'd eaten previously in my life was a pale imitation of these little bits of Heaven.
13133 The sushi came out fast, even though it was fairly busy this particular Thursday.
13134 The first thing I noticed, naturally, was that someone put a burning sugar cube on the tray.
13135 "Hey, fire!"
13136 I thought.
13137 It was a nice touch.
13138 Then I saw, nestled between the flaming sugar and the wad of wasabe, a small pile of what looked like pickle relish.
13139 I guessed what it was, and our waitress confirmed it: it was FRESH wasabe.
13140 Real, fresh-grated wasabe is something most people never experience.
13141 Most people don't even know the pasty green stuff that's standard in every sushi restaurant is just normal horseradish dyed green.
13142 The real stuff is just too expensive, and too difficult to keep on hand.
13143 But there it was, no extra charge.
13144 It adds a little spice and a wonderful, fruity complexity to the sushi.
13145 The sushi was great.
13146 They also have a large menu with all the other Japanese dishes you'd expect, but I didn't try any of them.
13147 Next time.

13149 I have never cared for the place....so I definitely won't miss it.
13150 However if your looking for some decent electronic gear at 60-80% off....then this is your weekend to go.
